dcterms:creator: W. Poundstone
dcterms:description: The dataset represents the classic Prisoner's Dilemma Game (PDG), which is a fundamental model in game theory used to study cooperation and conflict.
dcterms:title: Prisoner's Dilemma Game (PDG)

dcterms:creator: A. Szolnoki
M. Perc
dcterms:description: The Fermi rule is a mechanism used in evolutionary game theory to model the dynamics of strategy adoption based on the success of neighboring strategies.
dcterms:title: Fermi rule

dcterms:creator: R. Axelrod
dcterms:description: Tit-for-Tat (TFT) is a strategy in game theory where a player responds to an opponent's action with the same action, promoting cooperation.
dcterms:title: Tit-for-Tat (TFT)

dcterms:creator: X. Han
X. Zhao
H. Xia
dcterms:description: The Bush-Mosteller model is a reinforcement learning model that describes how agents update their strategies based on past experiences.
dcterms:title: Bush-Mosteller model

dcterms:creator: X. Han
X. Zhao
H. Xia
dcterms:description: This dataset represents a hybrid learning approach that combines social learning with the Bush-Mosteller model to enhance cooperation.
dcterms:title: Hybrid learning combining social learning and the Bush-Mosteller model

dcterms:creator: C. Watkins
P. Dayan
dcterms:description: Q-learning is a model-free reinforcement learning algorithm that aims to learn the value of actions in a given state to maximize cumulative rewards.
dcterms:title: Q-learning

dcterms:creator: R. S. Sutton
A. G. Barto
dcterms:description: Reinforcement Learning (RL) is a framework for learning optimal behaviors through interactions with an environment, based on rewards and punishments.
dcterms:title: Reinforcement Learning (RL)

dcterms:creator: A. Bandura
R. H. Walters
dcterms:description: Social learning is a theory that suggests individuals learn behaviors by observing and imitating others, particularly those who are rewarded.
dcterms:title: Social learning

dcterms:creator: W. Hamilton
dcterms:description: Kin selection is a mechanism of natural selection that favors altruistic behaviors towards relatives, enhancing the survival of shared genes.
dcterms:title: Kin selection

dcterms:creator: R. L. Trivers
dcterms:description: Direct and indirect reciprocity are mechanisms that explain how cooperation can evolve through mutual benefit and reputation effects.
dcterms:title: Direct and indirect reciprocity

dcterms:creator: M. A. Nowak
R. M. May
dcterms:description: Network reciprocity refers to the phenomenon where individuals are more likely to cooperate if they are connected in a network, enhancing cooperative behavior.
dcterms:title: Network reciprocity

dcterms:creator: L. Keller
dcterms:description: Group selection is a theory in evolutionary biology that suggests natural selection can act at the level of groups, favoring cooperative behaviors.
dcterms:title: Group selection

dcterms:creator: K. Sigmund
C. Hauert
M. A. Nowak
dcterms:description: The dataset explores the dynamics of punishment and reward in promoting cooperation within populations.
dcterms:title: Punishment and reward

dcterms:creator: F. C. Santos
M. D. Santos
J. M. Pacheco
dcterms:description: Social diversity refers to the variety of strategies and behaviors within a population that can influence cooperation dynamics.
dcterms:title: Social diversity

dcterms:creator: L. Ma
J. Zhang
G. Zheng
R. Liang
L. Chen
dcterms:description: This dataset represents a bimodal mixture of the Fermi rule and Tit-for-Tat strategies, exploring their combined effects on cooperation.
dcterms:title: Bimodal mixture of Fermi rule and TFT
